skills.name: Identify the factors of prime numbers

explanations.A: Not quite, though it is the smallest number there, remember that a prime number has EXACTLY two factors, 1 AND itself. 1 only has 1 factor. Have another think :)
explanations.B: A prime number has to have exactly 2 factors, 1 and itself. 1 is smaller, however it is not a prime number because it only has 1 factor (1!)
explanations.C: You're not quite right, you're correct that 3 is a prime number :) however it is not the smallest prime in this list.
explanations.D: I think you've mistaken what a prime number is, remember a prime number has exactly two factors, 1 and itself, that means it cannot be divided by any other number. 4 can be divided by 2, so it is not prime. Have another go :)

explanations.A: Not quite, though it is the smallest number there, remember that a prime number has EXACTLY two factors, 1 AND itself. 1 only has 1 factor. Have another think :)
explanations.B: A prime number has to have exactly 2 factors, 1 and itself. 1 is smaller, however it is not a prime number because it only has 1 factor (1!)
explanations.C: I think you've mistaken what a prime number is, remember a prime number has exactly two factors, 1 and itself, that means it cannot be divided by any other number. 4 can be divided by 2, so it is not prime. Have another go :)
explanations.D: You're not quite right, you're correct that 5 is a prime number - yay! :) however it is not the smallest prime number in this list.

explanations.A: I think we need to revise prime and square number definitions - try having another go using the fact that a prime number has exactly two factors, 1 AND itself (where itself is different), and that a square number is the result of one number multiplied by itself, for example 3x3=9, 9 is a square number :)
explanations.B: Square numbers are formed as a result of multiplying two identical whole numbers together. Since 1 ✕ 1 = 1, this fits the definition, and so 1 is a square number. It is not prime, though, because it does not have two distinct (or different) factors. It has only one factor.
explanations.C: Not quite, remember that a prime number has EXACTLY two factors, 1 AND itself. Have another think :)
explanations.D: Not quite, let's remind ourselves about what a square number is: the result of one number multiplied by itself, for example 3x3=9, so 9 is a square number :)

explanations.A: 2 is a prime number but it is not a square number. 2 only has two factors, 1 and itself, making it prime but as there is no whole number that you can multiply by itself, to get an answer of 2, it is not a square number.
explanations.B: Not quite. Square numbers are numbers that can be made by multiplying a whole number by itself, for example 4 is a square number as 2 ✕ 2 = 4. Is 2 a prime number?
explanations.C: Not quite. Remember square numbers are numbers that can be made by multiplying a whole number by itself, for example 4 is a square number as 2 ✕ 2 = 4. Is 2 a prime number?
explanations.D: Not quite. At least one of Tom and Katie is correct. Remember a prime number is a number that has only two factors, 1 and itself, and a square number is any number that can be made by multiplying any whole number by itself, for example 4 is a square number as 2 ✕ 2 = 4.

explanations.A: Let's remind ourselves of what a prime number is :) a number with exactly two factors, so it cannot be divided by anything other than 1 and itself. Can you think of any numbers that 21 can be divided by?
explanations.B: A prime number has to have exactly 2 factors, 1 and itself. 23 can only be divided by 1 and 23. 21 can be divided by 1,3,7,21 and 27 can be divided by 1,3,9,27, so neither 21 or 27 are prime.
explanations.C: Let's remind ourselves of what a prime number is :) a number with exactly two factors, so it cannot be divided by anything other than 1 and itself. Can you think of any numbers that 27 can be divided by?
explanations.D: Let's remind ourselves of what a prime number is :) a number with exactly two factors, so it cannot be divided by anything other than 1 and itself. Have you found more than two factors for all of the three options?

explanations.A: Let's remind ourselves of what a prime number is :) a number with exactly two factors, so it cannot be divided by anything other than 1 and itself. 81 can be divided by 1,3,9,27,81.
explanations.B: Let's remind ourselves of what a prime number is :) a number with exactly two factors, so it cannot be divided by anything other than 1 and itself. 33 can be divided by 1,3,11,33.
explanations.C: Let's remind ourselves of what a prime number is :) a number with exactly two factors, so it cannot be divided by anything other than 1 and itself. 121 can be divided by 1,11,121.
explanations.D: A prime number has to have exactly 2 factors, 1 and itself. 81 can be divided by 1,3,9,27,81, and 33 can be divided by 1,3,11,33 and 121 can be divided by 1,11,121 so none of them are prime.

explanations.A: Let's remind ourselves of what a prime number is :) a number with exactly two factors, so it cannot be divided by anything other than 1 and itself. 49 can be divided by 1,7 and 49, so is not prime.
explanations.B: Let's remind ourselves of what a prime number is :) a number with exactly two factors, so it cannot be divided by anything other than 1 and itself. 51 can be divided by 1,3,17,51, so is not prime
explanations.C: A prime number has to have exactly 2 factors, 1 and itself. 49 can be divided by 1,7,49, 51 can be divided by 1,3,17,51 and 55 can be divided by 1,5,11,55. 53 can only be divided by 1 and 53, so is the only prime number in the list.
explanations.D: Let's remind ourselves of what a prime number is :) a number with exactly two factors, so it cannot be divided by anything other than 1 and itself. 55 can be divided by 1,5,11,55, so is not prime.

explanations.A: Let's remind ourselves of what a prime number is :) a number with exactly two factors, so it cannot be divided by anything other than 1 and itself. 39 can be divided by 1,3,13,39, so is not prime.
explanations.B: A prime number has to have exactly 2 factors, 1 and itself. 39 can be divided by 1,3,13,39, 45 can be divided by 1,3,5,9,15,45 and so are not prime, and 43 is prime because it can only be divided by 1 and 43, however 41 is the first prime after 37.
explanations.C: You're very close! :) 43 is indeed a prime number, however there is another prime number between 37 and 43 :)
explanations.D: Let's remind ourselves of what a prime number is :) a number with exactly two factors, so it cannot be divided by anything other than 1 and itself. 45 can be divided by 1,3,5,9,15,45, so is not prime.

explanations.A: A prime number has exactly two factors, so it cannot be divided by anything other than 1 and itself. These numbers are quite high, and so you have to test whether they can be divided by quite a few numbers. To test a number below 100 is prime, you just have to try dividing by all the prime numbers below 10 (2,3,5,7). 87 is divisible by 1,3,29,87 and so is not a prime. 83 is only divisible by 1 and 83, so is prime.
explanations.B: Let's remind ourselves of what a prime number is :) a number with exactly two factors, so it cannot be divided by anything other than 1 and itself. These numbers are quite high, and so you have to test whether they can be divided by quite a few numbers. To test a number below 100 is prime, you just have to try dividing by all the prime numbers below 10 (2,3,5,7). Have another go at working out the answer :)
explanations.C: Not quite, let's remind ourselves of what a prime number is :) a number with exactly two factors, so it cannot be divided by anything other than 1 and itself. These numbers are quite high, and so you have to test whether they can be divided by quite a few numbers. To test a number below 100 is prime, you just have to try dividing by all the prime numbers below 10 (2,3,5,7). Have another go at working out the answer :)
